Configuration.StudyNameEntrez: Human Dorsal Root Ganglion PolyA RNA Seq Dataset
Configuration.StudyNameReportPage: Human Dorsal Root Ganglion PolyA RNA Seq Dataset
Configuration.Description: PolyA+ RNA sequencing was performed on human DRGs and were contrasted to a panel of relevant human and mouse RNA-seq studies (integrating, among other sources, datasets from ENCODE and GTex) in order to identify tissue-specific gene expression and alternative splicing in DRG, and contrasting the human and mouse DRG transcriptomes. Relevant sets of DRG-specific genes and splice variants were identified in human and mouse in a high-throughput way, creating a roadmap for future studies for deeper analysis of these transcripts from a molecular biological and pharmacological (in the context of chronic pain) perspective. Additionally, human DRG transcriptomes from donors suffering from chronic pain were contrasted with donors with no history of chronic pain.
Configuration.StudyInEx:
Inclusion criteria: No explicit inclusion criteria, except that all subjects were organ donors.

Exclusion criteria: All subjects needed to be adult humans, with intact DRGs at the time of post-mortem extraction.

Journal.authors: Torck A, Kim J, Zhang M, Dussor G, Price T, Ray P
Journal.title: RNA-seq based transcriptome profiling of human and mouse dorsal root ganglia provides insights into potential new pain targets
Journal.journal: The Journal of Pain, Apr 2016, Vol 17, Issue 4, Supplement, S44

Journal.authors: Lam T, Torck A, Dussor G, Price T, Ray P
Journal.title: A public resource to explore and compare the human and mouse dorsal root ganglion (DRG) transcriptome
Journal.journal: The Journal of Pain, Apr 2016, Vol 17, Issue 4, Supplement, S49

Header.title: Principal Investigator
Header.Institution: Brain and Behavioral Sciences, The University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX, USA

Header.title: Funding Source
Header.Institution: National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA

Url.name: UT Dallas - Pain Neurobiology Research Group

Configuration.StudyHistory: This study is part of a broader set of studies performed at the Pain Neurobiology Research Group at The University of Texas at Dallas, characterizing the "sensory transcriptome". We integrated high throughput transcriptome-profiling assay data for multiple species, across multiple sensory cell types and tissues, and across healthy and pain states to help characterize the role of specific transcripts or transcript sets in sensory neuronal function, disease and as drug targets.

DacInfo.DacFullName: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

ParticipantSet.UseLimitation: Use of the data is limited only by the terms of the model Data Use Certification.
